articles.title: About
articles.contents:
Resume ~
Click here for a pdf of my
resume!
Interests ~
Some people have an idea about how they want to spend their life from
a very young age — a calling so-to-speak, beckoning them in a certain
direction. I’ve never been that way: almost everything interests me.
I’ve always wanted to embrace all of my different passions and try to
find some way to make them all work together, which is exactly what I’ve
been able to explore and formulate throughout my undergraduate
education. I am now pursuing a Master of Environmental Data Science in
hopes of learning more about how to translate my synthesis of interests
to a more professional setting and enhance my confidence in solving
complex technical problems.
I gravitated toward the interdisciplinary field of Environmental
Studies in my undergraduate studies, despite arriving undeclared.
However, by the end of my second year, I, expectedly, felt there was
still more to explore, and decided to undertake two more majors in
Linguistics and History of Art and Architecture. Through the three very
different, yet interconnected, lenses, I have been fostering a greater
passion for computational data methods and opening my mind to a depth of
issues in urbanism and sustainability. Without these different lenses, I
would feel much less prepared to help tackle the complex issues that
exist in our society today. In graduate school and beyond, I would like
to apply these lenses to analyzing urban-centered socio-environmental
topics, such as food insecurity, urban forestry, public health, noise
pollution, and city planning, improving the sustainability and equity of
cities.

articles.title: Erika Egg
articles.contents:
Erika Egg's Portfolio

          About
          R Projects
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Erika Egg

                        Email
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            Erika Egg has always had a wide variety of interests and
            has strived to continuously embrace all of her different
            passions. During her undergraduate education at UC Santa
            Barbara, where she entered as a Regents Scholar, she decided
            to triple major in Environmental Studies, Linguistics
            (Emphasis in Language and Speech Technologies), and History
            of Art and Architecture (Emphasis in Architecture and
            Environment), graduating in 2022 with highest honors and
            membership in Phi Beta Kappa. During this time, she
            developed a greater passion for computational data analysis
            methods and a depth of issues at the intersection of her
            three primary fields of study. Her research experience has
            included lab, field, and data analysis work related to
            marine chemical analysis, landscape restoration, urban
            forestry, food security, and the environmental impacts of
            COVID-19.
            She is now pursuing a Master of Environmental Data
            Science at UC Santa Barbara’s Bren School of Environmental
            Science & Management and hopes to apply her
            interdisciplinary lens to analyzing urban-centered
            socio-environmental topics, resulting in the improvement of
            the quality and sustainability of human interactions with
            built and natural environments. Concurrently, she assists
            with research data management for the Arctic Data Center at
            the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis
            (NCEAS).
          
        
      
    

    
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Erika Egg
